SummaryOfEvents:
FLAG STATE REPORT

Loaded with 30,884 tonnes of fuel oil Erika sailed from Dunkirk to Livorno Italy on 8 December 1999.  On 11 December, while crossing the Bay of Biscay, she encountered rough seas and a west/south-westerly force 9 gale.  The Master attempted to correct a progressive starboard list and transmitted a distress alert.

When checking cargo and ballast tank ullages, the previously empty no. 2 segregated ballast tank was found to be more or less equal to sea level and two thirds full of water and fuel oil, but less than the level in the adjacent no. 3 centre cargo oil tank.  Cracks and buckling were noticed on deck in way of no. 2 starboard segregated ballast tank. The Master decided to head for the nearest port of refuge.

The list was corrected.  The distress alert changed to a safety message which was later cancelled.  During the night the starboard list reoccurred, and attempts to correct it were unsuccessful.  Meanwhile the cracks on deck widened.

On 12 December large quantities of oil were observed escaping to the sea.  Later part of the shell plate of no. 2 segregated ballast tank was seen to have torn away.  A second distress alert was transmitted.  As some of the crew were evacuated by a French naval helicopter the vessel broke in two.  Because the helicopter winch broke down, the crew remaining were evacuated by the port lifeboat and a second French naval helicopter.

COASTAL STATE REPORT

On 11 December 1999, the tanker Erika, laden with 30,884 tons of heavy (no. 2) fuel oil, was sailing from Dunkirk to Livorno, Italy.  While crossing the Bay of Biscay in foul weather, the tanker suffered a structural failure.  After a significant list was corrected, the hull broke in two crosswise some 30 nautical miles south of Pointe de Penmarcโh, Brittany.  The two halves of the vessel then sank in about 120 metres despite attempts to tow the stern portion offshore.

The whole crew of the Erika was safely evacuated by the National Navy under the co-ordination of the Atlantic regional search and rescue operations centre (CROSS - Centre Regional Opรฉrationnel de Surveillance et de Sauvetage) at รtel.  Following the shipwreck, a large part of the vesselโs cargo and bunker oil spilled into the sea.  This oil spill, abetted by difficult weather conditions, affected several hundred kilometres of coastline from the tip of Brittany to รle de Rรฉ.

SummaryOfEvents: While the ALCOR (see other record : incident ref. C0002538) was being refloated and later, while the vessel was upbound with the assistance of tugs, the Traverse du Nord section of the river was temporarily closed.  The closure caused several downbound vessels to anchor upriver.  The subsequent re-opening of the channel resulted in a confluence of vessels wishing to depart their anchorages.  During this time, a near-collision occurred between the tanker ETERNITY, under way, and the container ship CANMAR PRIDE, at anchor.

SummaryOfEvents:
On 9 November 1999, the loaded bulk carrier ALCOR was upbound for Trois-Riviรจres, Quรฉbec, on the St. Lawrence River, under the conduct of a pilot.  At 14h44, while undertaking a course alteration to starboard, the vessel ran aground near the eastern end of รle d'Orlรฉans.  A refloating attempt the next evening succeeded in freeing the vessel, but only briefly, and the vessel grounded a second time near the initial grounding position.   The ALCOR sustained major hull damage near midships due to bending forces incurred during successive low-tide cycles.
The damaged hull was temporarily repaired and roughly half of the cargo was discharged onto smaller vessels.  On December 5th, the ALCOR was refloated and conducted to the port of Quรฉbec.  It was declared a constructive total loss.

Location: Off the west coast of the Island of Mull

Location: 120 miles S.W. of Florida, Gulf of Mexico
SummaryOfEvents: The Liberian registered passenger vessel TROPICALE suffered a fire in her engine room at 18:05LT on September 19, 1999.  The TROPICALE was completing a four day cruise originating and concluding in Tampa, with ports of call in Key West, Florida and Cozumel, Mexico.  The fire resulted in no deaths or injuries to passengers or crew and there was no pollution.  However, both of the vessel's engines were disabled.  Concurrently, the tropical storm "harvey" was approaching with high seas and winds up to 50mph.  The crew was able to restart the starboard engine and the TROPICALE began moving at 9-10mph in a southwesterly direction, away from "Harvey".  When "Harvey" veered south, the TROPICALE altered course back towards Tampa.  Unfortunately continuing engine trouble and rough seas forced TROPICALE to abort her efforts to reach Tampa and she finally berthed at Port Manatee, 30 miles south of Tampa.  She arrived on September 22, 1999, two days behind schedule.

SOLASStatus: EVER DECENT: Unknown/unspecified, NORWEGIAN DREAM: Unknown/unspecified
Location: eastern approaches to the Dover Strait
SummaryOfEvents:
The Ever Decent was en route to Zeebrugge from Thamesport under pilotage on a clear night with good  visibility and fair weather conditions.  She was to cross the SW Traffic Separation Zone in the region of the F3 Buoy.

The ship Norwegian Dream was southbound for Dover, it is assumed at reduced speed in order to effect a daylight arrival for disembarkation and embarkation of passengers.

Both were well-found ships owned and operated by shipping companies of international repute.

Despite visual sightings and with verbal contact having  been established with Norwegian Dream after light signal from the Ever Decent, collision occurred at approximately at approximately 0155 Z+2 in approximate position 51 26 N  01  56 E. on 24 August 1999.

Norwegian Dreamโs bow collided with Ever Decent in way of No 3 Hold. The ships separated immediately after impact, with both having sustained heavy damage.

CAUGHT FIRE IN LAT. 53 28.7N., LONG. 02 55.5E., ON 18/8/99. ABANDONED BY CREW. TOWED INTO YMUIDEN 20/8/99. TOWED TO GDYNIA, WHERE ARRIVED 31/3/00 TO BE BROKEN UP. 
CREW ABANDONED VESSEL, BUT LATER REBOARDED IN AN ATTEMPT TO EXTINGUISH THE BLAZE. AT FIRST IT APPEARED TO HAVE BEENBROUGHT UNDER CONTROL, BUT IT SUBSEQUENTLY REGAINED STRENGTH AND DESTROYED THE ACCOMMODATION. AT THIS POINT THE CREW RE-EVACUATED VESSEL. FIRE WAS REPORTED TO BE OUT, APART FROM SMOKE, ON 19/8/99, BUT STARTED UP AGAIN DURING THE NIGHT. VESSEL WAS REPORTED TO BE TOTALLY BURNT OUT

Location: St. Lawrence Seaway, S side Cornwall Channel
SummaryOfEvents: The sunny Blossom was on Lac Saint-Franรงois bound for Cornwall, Ontario, in daylight and in reduced visibility. A pilot, accompanied by an apprentice pilot, had the conduct of the vessel. Following a course alteration off Pointe Dupuis, the ship ran aground upstream of buoy D36 on the north side of the channel at 07:30 hours. The grounding caused some delays to ship traffic in the area. The ship was refloated the following day with the assistance of a tug. The grounding did not cause damage to the Sunny Blossom or pollution. No one was injured.

At 6.47HRS (PST) on July 15th 1999, M/T. Cherry Galaxy tried to sail out from Lynnterm No 4(DOW), her last port in Canada with pilot and two tugs. While unberthing, two tugs did not take the proper tug lines other than push on fore and aft of ship, even if ship's master asked to pilot to take tug line but his recommendation was disregarded by pilot.
After immediate unberth, ship was affected by current easterly and approached toward 2nd narrow bridge too fast and closely and her eng was used astern/aheard propulsion by pilot and master, fortunately did not happen any problem against 2nd narrow bridge but, unfortunately ship contacted with jetty where does not installed any fenders.
(actually those fenders were missed and remained about 20cm height of steel pad eyes on side of Jetty). Concurrently, ship had damage of 2 bigs holes on shell plating at port quater, where is eng room compartment about 2 meters higher of sea level. Other than above hull damage, there were no injury of crew, no further damage of machineries and equipment reported.
(For your information, The Bridge named 2nd Narrow bridge is locating at about 200 meters eastward of Lynnterm No4, Vancouver).
